children: ) appear sharply demarcated or “punched out” with a dry pale, gray, or yellow base, and the surrounding skin is red, taut, and tender. Arterial ulcers are more likely to occur on the toes, plantar surfaces of the foot, and the heel. Venous stasis ulcers (

) are typically less painful and occur on the medial side of the lower leg (between the calf and the ankle) in areas of hyperpigmentation. Venous ulcers are typically irregularly shaped and shallow with yellow granulation tissue. They often weep serous fluid; the ulcers are rarely necrotic.
